properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong northwesterly winds will whip up snow and give blizzard conditions over these communities today. Conditions should improve through the evening. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-18T01:11:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-17T09:12:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1259845923.2020
Area: Ivujivik, Akulivik, Puvirnituq, Inukjuak, Umiujaq, Kuujjuarapik, Salluit, Sanikiluaq
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow today through early Wednesday morning; poor visibility and locally 10 to 20 cm of snow expected. Hazards: Whiteout conditions in heavy and blowing snow Snowfall amounts of 10 to 20 cm locally Timing: Heavy flurries will start later this morning and last through tonight. The worst snow squall conditions are expected later this afternoon and this evening. Impacts: Motorists should be prepared for hazardous winter driving conditions. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-18T07:47:06-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-17T15:48:06-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1195660767.2020

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Visibilities will be near zero at times today with the snow and the strong winds. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for today. This Winter Weather Travel Advisory is changed from a Snow Squall Watch that was previously in effect. Brief periods of low visibility in heavy flurries are expected; locally 5 to 15 cm of snow is possible. Hazards: Brief periods of low visibility in heavy snow and blowing snow Snowfall amounts of 5 to 15 cm locally Timing: Heavy flurries will last through this morning. More heavy flurries are possible this afternoon and early this evening. Impacts: Motorists should be prepared for hazardous winter driving conditions. The morning commute may be impacted. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-18T00:48:11-00:00

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Areas of dense fog persist over portions of southern Saskatchewan early this morning. Strengthening southeast winds should start lifting the fog later this morning in most areas. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected. A Pacific storm will bring heavy snow to the region today and tonight. Snow began earlier this morning and will intensify today. The snow will persist through this evening before tapering off overnight. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An intense low pressure system tracking northeast over Hudson Strait is giving strong north winds to Coral Harbour. North to northwest winds as high as 60 gusting 80 km/h will cause blowing snow and reduced visibility today with gradual improvement expected tonight. The potential still exists for blizzard conditions today with visibilities at times 400 metres or less. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-18T04:59:59-00:00

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A low pressure centre off north Vancouver Island will track northwards across Queen Charlotte Sound this afternoon. Over exposed coastal areas of North Vancouver Island and the Central Coast, southeast winds 90 gusting to 110 km/hr will persist this morning and shift to southwest 90 gusting to 110 km/hr this afternoon. Winds are expected to fall below warning criteria late this afternoon. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-18T01:59:33-00:00

A vigorous cold front will push across the central BC interior this afternoon with winds in the South Cariboo and 100 Mile regions rising to southerly 60 to 80 km/h. properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. A Pacific frontal system moving across northern BC is bring heavy snow to the Peace River District. For the south Peace River region, heavy snow will ease to light snow early this afternoon. For the north Peace River region, snow will persist through the afternoon and ease to periods of light snow later this evening. Total snowfall amounts near 15 cm are expected in the Peace River Region. As the frontal system moves northward, heavy snow will spread to Fort Nelson region this afternoon and continue through tonight. Snowfall amounts of 15 to 25 cm are expected in the Fort Nelson region before the snow tapers off Wednesday morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-18T08:11:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-17T16:12:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1014793349.2020
Area: B.C. South Peace River, B.C. North Peace River, Fort Nelson
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. Heavy snow is developing over northwestern Alberta and will move eastward throughout the day. A total of 10 to 15 cm of snow is expected by Wednesday morning. The heaviest snow should stay north of the town of Peace River, where amounts of 2 to 4 cm are more likely. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Lake effect snow squall bands are coming onshore between Grand Bend and Port Albert and are expected to intensify later this morning. The snow squalls will continue through the day and into tonight. Local snowfall amounts of 15 to 20 cm in 12 hours are likely. Snow squalls will taper off early Wednesday morning. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall amounts of 20 to 30 cm expected today A deep low pressure system off Vancouver Island will move north towards the north coast today. Snow at times heavy is expected to begin early this morning and will end late this evening as the low moves to the north. In addition, strong north winds of 50 km/h gusting to 70 will give widespread areas of blowing snow. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Sustained southeast winds of 80 to 110 km/h will continue over West Vancouver Island as a strong low moves past the south coast. Winds will veer to southwest 50 to 70 km/h behind the low around midday and ease further this afternoon. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A rapidly deepening area of low pressure is passing through north Vancouver Island while a fast moving cold front crosses the south coast. In advance of the cold front, strong sustained southeasterly winds are expected for coastal areas in proximity to the Strait of Georgia and Haro Strait. As the front races across the area, widespread and powerful gusty southerly winds will occur. Gusts in excess of 90 km/h are possible. Winds will ease considerably following the passage of the cold front but will remain gusty into this afternoon. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-17T23:59:17-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A Pacific storm will bring heavy snow and strong winds to the region today and tonight. 10 to 15 cm of snow is expected today and an additional 10 to 15 cm tonight. Gusty northeasterly winds have developed this morning and will persist until at least this evening. The strong winds will cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow. Conditions should improve by early Wednesday morning as the storm system exits the region. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-18T10:53:50-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-17T18:54:50-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3791425853.2020
Area: Highway 97 - Pine Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A deep low off Vancouver Island will move north towards the north coast today. Strong northerly outflow winds of 80 to 100 km/h will develop near Portland inlet this morning and persist into early this afternoon. Winds will ease late this afternoon as the low moves inland. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-18T02:39:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-17T12:24:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0138688998.2020
Area: North Coast - coastal sections
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A pacific storm will bring heavy snow to the region tonight and Tuesday. Heavy snow over Chilcotin will end overnight. Snow will spread to Stuart - Nechako late this evening and persist through midday Tuesday before tapering off. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
